title: Luminous Crossings
address: City Hall LRT Station (Third St. S.E.)
short_desc: This interactive public art installation consists of 20 components: two large-scale vertical sculptures, plus three hanging works, on four stations located at either end of the Seventh Avenue LRT line.
desc1: Referencing the idea of the living room or waiting area, there are four chandelier-like hanging sculptures in each canopy of the east and west gateway stations that give the waiting areas of the platforms a different quality. Additionally, their changing light show is a pleasant surrounding while waiting for the train.

title: Utility Box
address: Falconridge Blvd. N.E. at Falworth Rd. N.E. (N.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Southland Drive S.W. at 24th Street S.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Frozen River
address: Emergency Operations Centre (673 First St. N.E.)
short_desc: In suspended motion, like a Frozen River, this sculpture responds to Calgary's dramatic and varied landscape.
desc1: Beauty, force and nature. These elements inspired this grand sculpture, which pays tribute to the dramatic and ever-changing natural environment the Emergency Operations Centre is tasked with being responsive to.

title: Collected Stories: A Tribute to Georgina Thomson Library
address: Georgina Thomson Offices Exterior (772 Northmount Dr. N.W.)
short_desc: The public artwork for the latest incarnation of this historic building aims to honour the legacy of this former library and the late `answer lady' Georgina Thomson who worked here for many years.
desc1: Kari Woo developed her public art project to purposefully bridge the former use of the site with its new purpose as a neighbourhood services office.
desc2: Working alongside the local community and the family and friends of the late Georgina Thomson, she encouraged the exploration of the piece and its use in the new context to develop two installations that celebrate the site's past and present.
desc3: Outside the facility, Thomson's position as a librarian at this former library building is captured through a mini-library which invites visitors to take or leave a book. Beside this is a bench, engraved with the favourite quotes of community members, encouraging visitors to stop, gather and explore.

title: Chinook Arc
artist: Joe O'Connell and Blessing Hancock with Creative Machines (Technical Consultant)
address: Barb Scott Park (12th Ave. and Ninth St. S.W.)
short_desc: This artwork is an interactive, illuminated sculpture that responds to human interaction.
desc1: Illuminated at night, visitors have complete control over the lighting of the sculpture through an optical sensor that projects the movements and colors it sees onto the artwork's surface. Wave your hands, move colored objects or play a movie from your cell phone and witness the unique light sequence that takes shape.

title: Outflow
address: Parkdale Plaza (along the Bow River at the end of 34A St. N.W.)
short_desc: This inverted replica of Mount PeeChee, a mountain peak located north of Canmore along the Bow River, is the inspiration for this sculpture which merges form and function.
desc1: A memorial to the glacial origins of the Bow and its connection to shaping our community over the years, this functional sculpture allows the viewer to watch as our stormwater transitions from the urban environment back to the natural.
desc2: With the sculpture acting as a handrail, the bridge deck and surrounding Plaza areas allow the public to take a moment to observe, reflect and consider the impact we have on our environment.

title: Centre Street Bridge Lion
address: Municipal Building west entrance, 800 Macleod Tr. S.E
short_desc: This is one of the four concrete lions that originally graced the Centre Street Bridge.
desc1: The Centre Street Bridge Lions were modeled after the bronze lions at the base of Admiral Nelson's Monument in Trafalgar Square, London, England. One of the lions was restored in 1999 to produce a cast and mold that was used to create four new lions for the renovation of the Centre Street Bridge. This restored sculpture is now a part of the City's Public Art Collection and resides at the front doors of the Municipal Building for all citizens, tourists and future Calgarians to enjoy.

title: An Exchange of Words: A Community Book Exchange
address: Georgina Thomson Offices Interior (772 Northmount Dr. N.W.)
short_desc: The public artwork for the latest incarnation of this historic building aims to honour the legacy of this former library and the late `answer lady' Georgina Thomson who worked here for many years.
desc1: Kari Woo developed her public art project to purposefully bridge the former use of the site with its new purpose as a neighbourhood services office.
desc2: Working alongside the local community and the family and friends of the late Georgina Thomson, she encouraged the exploration of the piece and its use in the new context to develop two installations that celebrate the site's past and present.
desc3: The interior installation features a collection of collages, inspired by items collected during a workshop, which invited Calgarians to tell the story of the building and the woman it was named after.

title: Utility Box
address: Prestwick Gate S.E. and 52nd Street S.E. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Twin Bears
address: Baker Park, 9333 Scenic Bow Road N.W.
short_desc: Rearing up on their hind legs, these two young bears are getting ready to play.
desc1: Born in Polonne, Ukraine, Leo Mol first studied under his father, a commercial potter.  He later studied in Vienna and Berlin, before leaving Europe for Canada in 1948, settling in Winnipeg.
desc2: Although he was trained in a variety of artistic practices, he is best known for his sculptures of both people and animals. Many of his bronze works can be seen in Winnipeg, in the Leo Mol Sculpture Garden in Assiniboine Park.

title: Frozen Dreams
address: Max Bell Arena (1001 Barlow Tr. S.E.)
short_desc: Located in the entry area of the Max Bell Arena, this mural celebrates the sport of hockey.
desc1: Designed as a welcoming feature, the public artwork is intended to act as a document of the building's history, becoming a community scrapbook through the use of photographs and images provided by local teams and community members.
desc2: The result is an animated and celebratory experience which reflects the importance of hockey to this site and to Calgary.

title: José María Morelos y Pavon
address: Tomkins Park (17 Avenue and 8 Street S.W.)
short_desc: This bronze bust is a small piece of Mexican history that was generously given to the City of Calgary.
desc1: The man shown in the bust, José María Morelos y Pavon (1765-1815), was a key figure in the Mexican War of Independence. Both a Roman Catholic priest and a revolutionary, he led multiple campaigns for Mexican independence from the Spanish Empire.
desc2: Although he was executed prior the end of Spanish rule in 1821, he is widely respected as a Mexican hero whose efforts were essential to the country's autonomy.
desc3: The bust of Morelos was a gift to the City of Calgary from Mexico. It marks 200 years of Mexican independence. It was officially unveiled in Calgary's Tomkins Park on September 16, 2011, Mexico's annual day of independence.

title: Utility Box
address: Kensington Road N.W. and 10A Street N.W. (N.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Confluence
artist: David Dahlquist with RDG Dahlquist Art Studio
address: Martindale LRT Station (618 Martindale Blvd. N.E.)
short_desc: Weaving together the physical and symbolic connections of people and place, these two murals were designed by the artist and the community.
desc1: A combination of LED lighting, glazed terra cotta and laser-cut steel are featured on both sides of this exterior transit station. The viewer is invited to view the symbols created by the community members, their diversity highlighting how individually people can interpret their connection to a "place". Flowers, houses, maple leafs, cowboy boots and animals are just some of the elements which the community have defined as being significant to them, personally.
desc2: Dynamic and fluid in the day, this installation glows at night shifting the focus from the symbols to elements representing waves. This acknowledges the significance of our rivers, one of the most defining elements of our city; both an original mode of transportation and a common link to connect the stories of our history and the stories of today.

title: Utility Box
address: 13th Avenue S.W. and 37th Street S.W. (N.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Travelling Light
address: 96 Avenue N.E. (Near Airport Trail and Deerfoot Trail Interchange)
short_desc: Simple in form, yet bold in appearance, this functional and sculptural public art installation soars 17 meters into the sky.
desc1: Travelling Light is a site-specific sculpture that examines and brings to life the theme of movement. Functioning as a street lamp, the structure serves to frame the landscape around it. This large circular form makes reference to one of the oldest symbols of transportation in existence, the wheel.
desc2: Pedestrians, cyclists, vehicles, trains and planes all pass by this landmark, each engaging in their own specific mode of transportation. Motion and movement are referenced and united figuratively by a universal symbol, the circle.

title: Guardian
address: Manchester Centre entrance (25 Ave. S.E.)
short_desc: This steel sculpture towers over the site as if watching over or guarding this civic complex. Illuminated at night, it becomes a beacon of light marking the entry to the Manchester Centre.
desc1: The work refers to the notion of industrial units, one stacked upon the other, suggesting an inter-related dependence or a hierarchical infrastructure that relates to the current use of this civic site.

title: Columns (LRT Platform)
address: McKnight/Westwinds LRT Station (6200 36th St. N.E.)
short_desc: Located on the LRT platform, these historical images grace both sides of the supporting columns of the station roof. Viewed separately they are pieces of a story. Viewed in their entirety, the story is told.
desc1: Both sides of the columns have historical images sourced from Calgary's Glenbow Museum Archives. The images have been separated into segments, which align when the viewer stands at either end of the platform. One image is of a little girl riding a sheep and the other is of a lady standing on the back of a galloping horse.  Each image references the ranching history of this area, providing a sense of the past as the viewer journeys to their next destination.

title: Utility Box
address: 26th Avenue S.W. at 29th Street S.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Cracked Pot Foundations
address: Prince's Island Park (698 Eau Claire Ave. S.W.)
short_desc: The ideas for Ohe's sculptures are often based on something which would be unremarkable to anyone else.
desc1: As a young artist, chance played a role in her art. When a ceramic pot was accidentally destroyed in the kiln, she was intrigued by the shards. She imaginatively re-united the parts by creating abstract beings, with "heads" set on top of columnar "necks". The bisected elements of the spheres recall the broken vessel that had inspired her.

title: Brotherhood of Mankind
address: 1 Street SE between 5 Ave and 6 Ave
short_desc: These greatly elongated statues impress by their huge size, their extreme gauntness and their nudity.
desc1: Devoid of all social markers of individuality, race or class, the male and female figures embody all humanity as they interact. In two groups, outstretched arms and linked hands create physical and metaphoric bridges. Other figures face them, including a mother with a child. Disturbing to many in 1967, the statues are now a popular landmark, known as The Family of Man.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.W. and Beddington Trail N.W. (N.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Luminous Crossings
address: City Hall LRT Station (Third Street. S.E.)
short_desc: This interactive public art installation consists of 20 components: two large-scale vertical sculptures, plus three hanging works, on four stations located at either end of the Seventh Avenue LRT line.
desc1: These illuminated sculptures are integrated with Calgary's LRT system to change colours when the train arrives, docks and leaves the station. The structures of the sculptures are developed from images of rail transportation, connecting the artwork directly to the purpose and use of this site.

title: Utility Box
address: 26th Avenue S.W. at 37th Street S.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: bearing
address: Fire Apparatus and Repair Facility (1755 18th Ave. N.E.)
short_desc: Inspired by the unseen work behind the doors of the Fire Apparatus and Repair Facility this multi piece installation is an abstracted representation of fastening and moving systems.
desc1: The personnel in this facility play a vital and supporting role to the Calgary Fire Department.  As behind the scenes work often goes uncelebrated, the artist's vision was to bring outside a larger than life representation of what occurs within the inside of this facility.
desc2: The arch is inspired by locking and flat wave washers, modified to create an iconic arch.  Further down site is a sphere reminiscent of ball bearings which are an integral part of any moving system. Settled into the ground, these works become both a singular and united element dependent upon the viewers position.

title: Utility Box
address: Sarcee Trail N.W. at 112 Ave N.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: General James Wolfe
address: South Mount Royal Park (Quebec Avenue by Montcalm Crescent S.W.)
short_desc: This statue depicts General James Wolfe, a British army commander best known for his role in the 1759 Battle of the Plains of Abraham. Part of the Seven Years' War, this battle was between the British and French, and occurred near Quebec City.
desc1: This particular statue of Wolfe, created by Scottish-American sculptor John Massey Rhind in 1898, has travelled somewhat extensively. It was first located in New York, on the Exchange Court building, built by William Waldorf Astor, one of four statues Rhind made for that location.
desc2: Calgary philanthropist Eric Harvie eventually purchased the statue of Wolfe, which in 1967 was placed outside of Calgary's newly constructed planetarium. This placement was not without controversy: it was argued that the planetarium was not necessarily the best fit for an 18th-century officer.
desc3: It has since been relocated to what is perhaps its most fitting location: Calgary's South Mount Royal Park, which is bounded by Wolfe Street, Montcalm Crescent, and Quebec Avenue.

title: Utility Box
address: Falconridge Blvd. N.E. at Castleridge Dr. N.E. (S.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Confederation Focal Point
address: Confederation Park, 905 30 Avenue N.W.
short_desc: This monument was created in 1967 to mark Canada's 100th anniversary.
desc1: A curved wall shows a map of Canada, and below it, on the ground, is a stylized maple leaf. This maple leaf is made from a number of triangles, each formed from rock from a different province or territory. Together these triangles represent the country of Canada.
desc2: Although this work was a good representation of Canada in 1967, the map is now outdated: Nunavut is missing!
desc3: This installation was donated to The City of Calgary, built with funds raised by the Imperial Order Daughters of the Empire, a charitable organization.

title: Utility Box
artist: Jason Scott Johnson and Nicola Yssel Johnson
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.W. and Country Hills Square N.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Skywalk
address: Canyon Meadows pedestrian overpass (North of Canyon Meadows Drive)
short_desc: An image of a Chinook sky greets vehicles traveling along Macleod Trail South, while pedestrians using the overpass are invited to take a walk through the clouds.
desc1: This 14 panel frieze represents one of Calgary's most familiar weather conditions, the Chinook, a strong wind system which blows warmer air into the local environment, causing rapid temperature shifts and changing cloud formations.
desc2: On sunny days the artwork serves to blend the bridge infrastructure into its surrounding environment.  On cloudy days, it provides a reminder of sunny days to come.

title: Utility Box
address: 14th Street S.W. and 14th Avenue S.W. (N.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Natural Engineer
address: Park East of the Municipal Building, 800 Macleod Trail S.E.
short_desc: This life-size 'natural engineer' goes about his work without noticing the many people who pass by on their way to the Municipal Building Parkade.
desc1: Made by Cochrane-based sculptor Don Begg, this naturalistic bronze beaver is situated only a few blocks away from the Bow and Elbow Rivers.
desc2: Although these rivers flow through the heart of an urban centre, they are also the home of many creatures, including beavers.

title: Utility Box
address: Bow Trail S.W. at 33rd Street S.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Tracking the Trail
address: Highway 22X and McKenzie Meadows Drive S.E. (under the bridge)
short_desc: By the pathways of Fish Creek Park, elements of nature are combined to emphasize the uniqueness of this location where man and nature converge.
desc1: A walk through the site inspired the artist to create a multi-piece artwork, which is directly connected to this place. Whether man-made or natural in form, all of the elements from the paths to the animal tracks to the stone join together at this site.
desc2: The adjacent paths are referenced through the linear sections of stone. Local materials such as rock and stone are embedded within, a contrast in texture to the smooth granite that surrounds it.  Animal tracks are scattered throughout, just as they were during the artist's visit and as they continue to be each day.
desc3: Can you guess which creatures the artist discovered here on his journey?

title: Utility Box
address: Memorial Drive N.W. and Seventh Street N.W. (S.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Canyon Meadows Drive S.E. and Deer Ridge Drive S.E. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Joy
address: Municipal Building main floor, 800 Macleod Tr. S.E
short_desc: Although abstract, the upright orientation of the sculpture is strongly suggestive of a human form.
desc1: Flanking a central, bulbous "torso", two raised, tapering appendages seem to bend gracefully as if dancing. The dynamism and sense of movement are further enhanced by contrast. Highly burnished reflective surfaces are undercut by darker, textured areas that absorb light. Overall, the feeling conveyed is one of exuberance and joy, an emotional quality characteristic of this Edmonton's artist's sculptures.

title: Forest Lawn Lift Station
address: 19th Avenue and 26th Street S.E.
short_desc: An LED map of bar lights make up this unique to scale representation of the wastewater pipe system in the community of Forest Lawn. Connected to sensors that monitor the flow of wastewater in the pipes, the lights change colour based on flow levels.
desc1: Identified as a WATERSHED+ initiative, this project offered a unique opportunity to integrate art within the thinking and design of a new lift station. Lead artists Sans Façon focused on the process of revealing and connecting the importance of water in our daily lives at all stages of this project.
desc2: Lift stations are used throughout the city to lift wastewater from low-lying areas to higher areas where it can flow, using the force of gravity, to one of Calgary's wastewater treatment plants.
desc3: This installation is housed within the structure of such a facility, thereby allowing visitors to witness a small portion of the 4,500 kilometer wastewater system.

title: Utility Box
address: 21st Avenue S.W. and 14th Street S.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Fourth Street N.W. and 20th Avenue N.W. (N.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.W. and Country Hills Drive N.W. (N.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Pristine
address: 1 Street S.E. and 9 Avenue S.E. (Plus 15)
short_desc: Blake Senini's three-part work, "Pristine", brings images of nature inside to one of Calgary's many Plus-15 walkways. Layering and combining images of trees and oceans, the artist has created a work that offers subtle reminders of the natural world.
desc1: This multi-media work was created by projecting images onto aluminum panels that had been covered with a mixture of graphite and lacquer. The artist then etched the imagery into the panels, creating the works that you see here.
desc2: Senini is a Calgary-based artist who also teaches at the Alberta College of Art and Design. His work has been collected by many public and private organizations, including Glenbow Museum, the Alberta Foundation for the Arts, and the Canada Council Art Bank, among others.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.W. and Edgepark Blvd. N.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.E. and Country Village Way N.E. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: An Auspicious Find
address: Prince's Island Park pathway (698 Eau Claire Ave. S.W.)
short_desc: 15,000 marbles create images which reference the ecological environment a visitor might experience when visiting Prince's Island Park.
desc1: Four pixilated images represent the flora and fauna of the area in a spontaneous and unique fashion. The marbles shimmer and shift in colour depending on the time of day, while the images become abstracted the closer the viewer stands to the sculptures themselves. Look closely. Can you see yourself?

title: Utility Box
address: Elbow Drive S.W. and Anderson Road S.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: SWARM
address: 6th St. S.W. LRT Station
short_desc: Looking up and around, visitors to this LRT platform are surrounded by warmth and colour.
desc1: Vibrant colours meld with a swarm of leaf seeds whose chaotic patterns are not unlike those of transit commuters during rush hour; rushing and intermingling to move from here to there. These leaf seeds are also commonly referred to as keys. Can you find the other hidden keys in this installation?

title: Utility Box
address: Dover Ridge Drive S.E. at 36th Street S.E. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: The Bears
address: Municipal Building main floor, 800 Macleod Tr. S.E
short_desc: In this endearing sculpture, a mother bear and her cub stand with their backs to us.
desc1: Stylistically, their forms are simplified into broad masses, with the rear ends abruptly truncated to reveal the arches of their rounded bodies. Without textures or detail, it is the mother's gesture that signals her alertness. She turns around to confront you, the intruder. Oblivious, the cub continues to sniff the ground.

title: Water Garden
address: The City of Calgary Water Centre (625 Spiller Rd. S.E.)
short_desc: A sculptural installation in the lobby of the Water Centre is a dynamic statement, utilizing water to celebrate and draw attention to the services provided within this civic building.
desc1: This multi-piece installation brings nature into an interior environment by referencing natural elements in a striking and dynamic manner. There are notions of a wooded grove as seen through the angular, tall green poles, and a natural water source, referenced by the monumental columnar tank which mimics a babbling brook, animating this site with its bubbling and fluid movements.

title: Topiary
address: McKnight/Westwinds LRT Station (6200 36th St. N.E.)
short_desc: Located in the plaza area of the LRT station, this whimsical and distinctly unique sculpture is contemporary in nature, but historical in inspiration.
desc1: Topiaries are structures grown from nature, but designed by humans. They are often fanciful, featuring large geometric shapes or figural compositions. Complicated and detailed they are commonly viewed as living sculptures. In the artist's words a "...topiary sculpture is about cultivation and that can mean many things. It can be a cultivation of community, a cultivation of ideas or the cultivation of gardens and life."
desc2: References to the Blackfoot Nation have been included through the use of circles in both this and the metal quilt installation.  The Blackfoot, one of the oldest aboriginal nations to inhabit Calgary, often incorporate circles into many of their creations, and the inclusion of this motif acts as a way to continue their connection to this site and to the community of Calgary.

title: Utility Box
address: 17th Avenue S.W. and 47th Street S.W. (South side of intersection)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Crenellated Habitat
address: John Laurie Blvd. N.W. pedestrian overpass into Nose Hill Park
short_desc: Two sets of curved, steel panels flank either end of the "Whispering Grasses Walkway", a pedestrian overpass leading into Nose Hill Park.
desc1: Images relating to the natural environment are featured on these artworks, which welcome and entice the user to explore, investigate and enjoy the natural environment around them. The curvature and patina of the panels were purposefully selected by the artist to echo the architecture of the bridge. Impressions of bison, predators and even a topographical map can be found etched into the artworks' surfaces.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.E. and Coventry Hills Blvd. N.E. (S.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: The Colour of Snow
address: Nosehill Drive overpass at Crowchild Trail N.W .
short_desc: Conceptually and visually linked to the watercolour-like glass on the LRT station windows, the artwork in these railings is inspired by the artist's first visit to Calgary.
desc1: These 24 snowflake patterns emulate a snowstorm, drawing our attention to the unique forms that are built by nature, in an environment built by man. Pedestrians are able to enjoy the railings on a personal level, engaging with both the infrastructure and the shadows they cast as they walk by.

title: Strung II
address: Crowchild Trail N.W. (Sarcee Trail N.W. Overpass)
short_desc: Strung II is comprised of two installations; one in the piers of the underpass along Crowchild Trail N.W. and the other in the railings of the overpass along Sarcee Trail N.W.
desc1: When considering the site, the artist was drawn to barbed wire imagery feeling it would be appropriate given this location had been ranch land in the recent past. He felt the use of this imagery would help to connect the site to that history.
desc2: From this he developed two types of experiences. The first is the large sculptural forms of barbed wire perched within the centre piers of the bridge. These are highly visible from a distance, and by C-Train and vehicular commuters who pass by on their daily commute.
desc3: The second is the laser cut panels on the Sarcee Trail overpass, which allow for a more personal pedestrian experience. Eight panels are inset within the railing, their connection implying a continuous string of barbed wire running from one end to the other. On a sunny day they cast shadows on the bridge deck and provide an alternate viewpoint for those engaging with the site.

title: Utility Box
address: Macleod Trail S at Heritage Drive S.W. (N.W. Corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Bridge, Abridged
address: Overpass at Glenmore Tr. and Legsby Rd. N.W.
short_desc: Artwork appears throughout the sound walls, the bridge deck, the railings, and on the piers of the bridge itself, helping to tell the story of this sites development.
desc1: Inspired by the challenging requirements of this cantilevered bridge, the artist chose to reveal the complexities of engineering through his public art project.  Words and shapes help to highlight the unique design and construction of this cantilevered walkway. Basic principles of physics such as compressing, tension, and expansion are noted at critical locations throughout the site.
desc2: To learn more about this award winning design, visit the interpretive panel sitting at the base of the overpass.

title: Women are Persons!
address: Olympic Plaza: 228 8 Avenue S.E.
short_desc: A tea party is the setting for this group portrait representing the extraordinary achievement in 1929 of Alberta's Famous Five.
desc1: In period dress, animated women are shown as real people, not heroes. The open, circular composition invites you to enter into their midst. The figures face each other, not gazing outward as in a more traditional, elevated monument.  At the same time, the permanence of bronze and enhanced scale signify their stature in Canadian history.

title: Self-Made Woman
artist: Paul Slipper with Cameron Small and Amiel Logan
address: SAIT Polytechnic (1301 16 Avenue N.W.)
short_desc: In this work, artist Paul Slipper, along with Cameron Small and Amiel Logan, offer a literal and lighthearted interpretation of a self-made woman: here, we see the figure carving herself out of granite.
desc1: "Self-Made Woman" was carved during WorldSkills Calgary 2009, a competition that brought attention to the value of skilled work in the trades, as well as in technology and the service industry.
desc2: The sculpture, which was carved in Calgary's Olympic Plaza before being moved to the SAIT campus, has both rough and smooth surfaces. These surfaces show how the work was made, with general forms being carved out and then gradually refined to produce a smooth and finished surface.
desc3: Slipper trained at the Emily Carr School of Art (now the Emily Carr University of Art and Design) and currently lives in Vancouver.

title: TransitStory
address: Centre Street LRT Platform
short_desc: Enlivening the experience of the Centre Street LRT station are 30 sculptural commuters standing alongside transit users, collectively waiting for the next train to arrive.
desc1: Thousands of people wait in spontaneous collectivity on the LRT platform. In transit, they wait alone  - vaguely aware of the anonymous presence of others. Each individual shares a brief moment in time and space; a temporary moment of belonging.
desc2: TransitStory evokes the ephemeral presence and memory of travellers. Present and absent, seen and unseen, this work seeks to capture the fleeting trace of human presence within public space.

title: Utility Box
address: Seton Way S.E. at Market Street S.E. (N.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: 40th Avenue N.W. and Centre Street (N.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Playful Cubs
address: Baker Park, 9333 Scenic Bow Road N.W.
short_desc: In this lighthearted bronze sculpture, artist Leo Mol shows two young bear cubs playing with their mother. She seems patient and relaxed as her cubs practice their climbing skills on her.
desc1: Born in Polonne, Ukraine, Leo Mol first studied under his father, a commercial potter.  He later studied in Vienna and Berlin, before leaving Europe for Canada in 1948, settling in Winnipeg.
desc2: He was eventually commissioned to create sculpted busts of a number of prominent people, including prime ministers and royalty. He is also known for his sculptural depictions of wildlife, such as the work you see here.

title: Utility Box
address: Bow Trail S.W. and Waverly Drive S.W.
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Ex/Diamond
address: Plus 15 between Rocky Mountain House and the Central Library, 616 MacLeod Trail S
short_desc: This conceptual work of art explores the dividing lines between works of fine art and factory-produced advertisements.
desc1: Vera Gartley is a senior Calgary artist who taught at the Alberta College of Art and Design for many years. In this artwork, the text records a conversation the artist had with the manufacturer when she had the shapes made.
desc2: While the X and diamond look like advertisements, what they might be selling is unclear. Are they selling an idea? Or nothing at all? According to the artist, it is up to the viewer to decide just what this work of art might be trying to discuss.

title: Jumping Trout
address: Glenmore Trail, from Elbow Drive to Fifth Avenue S.W.
short_desc: Built into the retaining wall of Glenmore Trail, 144 trout are represented as if swimming and jumping along the waves in the near-by Bow River.
desc1: Rainbow trout and Brown trout are just five of the species which inhabit this nearby River, a renowned fly-fishing location. These relief forms are bolted into panels representing the water and the sky. Those jumping are highlighted by their colourful scales reflecting in the sun. Those swimming are muted from the dark water of the river.

title: Calgary Hawk Hill Sentinels
address: Ralph Klein Park (12350 84th St. S.E.)
short_desc: From a distance, visitors to Ralph Klein Park will notice three monolithic sculptures rising above two pyramid-like mounds. This is Hawk Hill Calgary Sentinels.
desc1: Rising into the sky, it is impossible not to feel the presence of the sculptural landforms. The mounds physically define this place, drawing us to them by their sheer presence, making us aware of the vastness of this site. The core-ten steel sculptures seem to be timeless in age, their massive forms highlighting the significance of this wetland location to our city and our environment.
desc2: "The monoliths...are meant to herald the uniqueness of the wetlands...(and) offer a place for reflection and contemplative thought..." - Beverly Pepper

title: Utility Box
address: Sarcee Trail S.W. at Bow Trail S.W. (N.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Body Mind Spirit
address: Southland Leisure Centre (2000 Southland Dr. S.W.)
short_desc: A lively mosaic greets any visitor entering the lobby of Southland Leisure Centre. Glass, text, ceramics and photography all combine to tell the story of this community focused site.
desc1: Images celebrating the activities hosted at this facility and the cultural diversity of the surrounding communities combine to highlight the importance of supporting the body, mind and spirit of the individual and the collective.
desc2: Details small and large are all intrinsic to this artwork, as seen through the artist's use of the word "welcome", translated into more than 30 languages, and incorporated this text throughout. Can you find them all?

title: Utility Box
address: 33 Street S.W. and 14th Avenue S.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: The Colour of Snow
address: Crowfoot LRT connector bridge, west side
short_desc: Conceptually and visually linked to the watercolour-like glass on the LRT station windows, the artwork in these railings is inspired by the artist's first visit to Calgary.
desc1: These 12 snowflake patterns emulate a snowstorm, drawing our attention to the unique forms that are built by nature, in an environment built by man. Pedestrians are able to enjoy the railings on a personal level, engaging with both the infrastructure and the shadows they cast as they walk by.

title: Utility Box
address: Memorial Drive N.W. and 5a Street N.W.
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.W. and Country Hills Village Entrance (S.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Charged Line
address: South Calgary Fire Station No. 5 (3129 14th St. S.W.)
short_desc: That immediate moment when water is first released into a hose, charging it to life is represented in this multi-sculptural installation, Charged Line.
desc1: Fire station No. 5 is one of the longest functioning stations in the City of Calgary. This sculptural installation, which spans the site of the original fire station walls, makes direct reference to not only the history of this site, but also the activities the Fire Department employs for the safety of our city.
desc2: The texture on the sculptures' columns references cloth hoses originally utilized by The Calgary Fire Department. The brass couplings located at the center and tops of the sculptures are reclaimed from retired City of Calgary fire hoses. In a manner similar to a cloth fire hose, the materials used purposefully change with age and will continue to alter in colour with exposure to the weather and time.

title: Utility Box
address: Fifth Street S.W. and Glenmore Trail S.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Bears
address: Century Gardens, 8th Avenue at 7th Street S.W.
short_desc: In this lighthearted bronze sculpture, artist Leo Mol shows two playful bears.
desc1: Born in Polonne, Ukraine, Leo Mol first studied under his father, a commercial potter.  He later studied in Vienna and Berlin, before leaving Europe for Canada in 1948, settling in Winnipeg.
desc2: Although he was trained in a variety of artistic practices, he is best known for his sculptures of both people and animals. Many of his bronze works can be seen in Winnipeg, in the Leo Mol Sculpture Garden in Assiniboine Park.

title: Utility Box
address: Canyon Meadows Drive S.E. and Queensland Drive S.E. (N.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Balancing Act
address: Municipal Building plaza level, 800 Macleod Tr. S.E
short_desc: Bright primary colours, imagination and welding transform utilitarian construction materials into a playful sculpture.
desc1: Like a brilliantly coloured industrial "tree", its red trunk is perched precariously on a single tapered point. Above, three discs scan the sky like whimsical satellite dishes. The vertical post is topped by a horizontal beam from which yellow and green I-beams soar up and away, creating an upward motion that counters the gravity-defying balancing act at the base of the structure.

title: Nimmons Cairn (Conic Sculpture)
address: Nimmons Park (1950 17A Street S.W.)
short_desc: This two-part abstract sculpture by celebrated artist Katie Ohe commemorates the Nimmons family, settlers who lived and worked on this land in the 19th century.
desc1: While this sculpture is a nod to the past, it is also meant to be enjoyed by current residents and visitors. Katie Ohe is known for creating interactive sculptures, and this geometric work is no different. Visitors are welcome to touch and sit upon this work, or even crawl under it if they are so inclined!
desc2: The artist who created this work was born in Alberta and continues to live here today. her works can be found across the city, in many different public locations. You may recognize her famous "Zipper" sculpture, located at the University of Calgary, or "Janet's Crown", located at the Alberta College of Art and Design (ACAD). Ohe has taught at ACAD for many years, and is a respected artist and teacher who is recognized as being an early practitioner of abstract sculpture in this province.

title: Utility Box
address: 14th Street and 24th Avenue N.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Triclopse
address: Multi Services Station (80th Avenue and Saddletowne Circle N.E.)
short_desc: Located at the front of the building, this installation features three unified sculptures, each representing one of the emergency services housed at this location.
desc1: Triclopse employs three aesthetic but functional sirens that represent the services provided by Police (copper), Fire (red) and EMS (silver) all of whom function out of this facility, working both separately and jointly as an active, unified set of protective services.
desc2: One commonality of these three organizations is their historical use of the siren as a means to alert the community. The sound of the siren is universally recognizable and is generated simply by directing a stream of air through holes that rapidly open and close. Most siren sounds today are produced electronically, but previously they were driven by electric motors or even hand-cranked.
desc3: The three wheels in this sculpture may be rotated individually by turning the crank on the sculptures base, however, the effort needed is considerable. When two or three viewers participate by turning all of the crank-wheels at the same time, the drums can be spun easier and faster, creating a louder sound.

title: Deux Chiens Assis
address: Sue Higgins Park (Southland Drive S.E. and Deerfoot Trail)
short_desc: Do you recognize these two dogs? For many years, this pair of bronze dogs - a bloodhound and a retriever - kept a watchful eye over Devonian Gardens in Calgary's downtown core.
desc1: Estimated to be crafted in the late 1800s, the two bronze dog statues attributed to artist Henri Jacquemart are titled Deux Chiens Assis, which means two seated dogs. They were gifted to the City of Calgary Public Art Collection by the Devonian Foundation in 1978.
desc2: The sculptures are now permanently installed near Nora Tuckey's Grove in Sue Higgins Park.  This park lies along the banks of the Bow River and is home to the largest fenced-off dog park in the city.
desc3: French artist Henri Alfred Marie Jacquemart was born in Paris in 1824 and passed away in 1896. He studied at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris and exhibited at the Paris Salon from 1847 to 1879. He is a well known sculptor of animals and monuments, and his works can be found in many museums including the Musee D'Orsay.

title: Ripple
address: 12 Street S.E. by 8 Avenue S.E.(parklet)
short_desc: Inspired by a River Blessing and generated in consultation with the local Inglewood community and representatives from the Blackfoot and Cree Nations, this walking circle is designed to be a meaningful vantage point from which to consider the river.
desc1: Seven pathways coil towards a central meditative space which hosts four motifs to represent the stages of life and compass points.
desc2: Birth (east) is represented by the eagle, an otter (south) signifies youth, middle age (west) is characterized by a beaver and the buffalo (north) embodies wisdom age.
desc3: The seven paths also represent the seven teachings of humility, respect, truth, courage, honesty, love and wisdom. There is a subtle break added to the walking circle, allowing a mythical river to symbolically flow through the circle.

title: Utility Box
address: 30th Avenue S.E. 36th Street S.E. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.W. and Beddington Trail N.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Bow Trail S.W. at Rosscarrock Gate S.W. (S.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Realidoscope
address: Mission Cliff Bungalow Promenade (Elbow Drive and 25th Ave S.W.)
short_desc: Realidoscope captures people, architecture and the natural environment found along the river pathway.
desc1: Looking through the viewfinder the reflected surroundings are accented by the ever-changing motion of nature and people around this site.
desc2: The artist believes the use of prisms lends itself to interactive situations and community involvement, and allows the viewer to engage in the act of transition and change. That we are living in a world which is continually being rearranged and reassembled, much like the way prisms rearrange our point of view in Realidoscope.

title: Under the Helmet
address: Windsor Park Fire Station (5536 4 St. S.W.)
short_desc: Under the Helmet is a large aluminum sculpture of a firefighter's helmet, constructed from the characteristics of retired City of Calgary Fire hoses.
desc1: While visually simple in form, the artwork speaks to the complex relationships and dependencies that exist among firefighters and their equipment; fusing the personal protection the helmet offers and the uniform it represents into a monument to the profession.
desc2: During his research into the firefighting community, the artist was taken with the significance this piece of equipment holds to members of the Calgary Fire Department. The helmet distinguishes the individuality of the firefighter while symbolizing membership on a team, and represents the challenges and the rewards firefighters experience while under the helmet.

title: Ascension
address: Poetic Park ( Fourth Avenue and Ninth Street S.W.)
short_desc: These two ascending creatures vary in scale and form depending upon the observer's viewpoint.
desc1: To the pedestrian they are larger than life, ascending and climbing throughout the landscape. To those in the neighbouring buildings, their form and motion define the space they inhabit.
desc2: Fabricated locally, these sculptures were purposefully constructed to be modular in nature, consisting of three sections to be assembled like a tripod. This format allowed the composition of each of the insects to be determined by the terrain of the park, as the three sections were able to be adjusted and formed to respond to the site itself. Each creature is the same, yet has its own unique perspective.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.E. and Country Hills Town Centre (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Topiary Quilts
address: McKnight/Westwinds LRT Station (6200 36th St. N.E.)
short_desc: Located near the parking entrance along the South side of the park-n-ride, these metal fence-like structures help define the boundary of this site.
desc1: Standing over seven feet in height, the images on the Quilts are directly related to the shapes and forms found in the Topiary sculpture located in the plaza area of the LRT station. They also reference the images dotted across the glass heating shelters on the station platform, continuing the playful dialogue the artists have featured throughout this site.
desc2: References to the Blackfoot Nation have been included through the artist's use of circle motifs, an element commonly found in many Blackfoot creations. The Blackfoot are one of the oldest aboriginal nations to inhabit Calgary, and the artist's inclusion of this imagery acts as a way to continue their historical connection to this site and to the community of Calgary as a whole.

title: Bird of Spring
address: Connaught Park, 14 Avenue and 11 Street S.W.
short_desc: This large sculpture of a stylized, majestic bird is based on a much smaller soapstone carving by artist Abraham Etungat.
desc1: Abraham Etungat (1911-1999) was an Inuit artist who lived in Nunavut. Etungat's family is quite also artistic: his wife, daughter, and grandson are all carvers. His work has been collected by many museums and galleries across Canada.
desc2: The original work is approximately 14 cm tall, while this enlarged version (which was approved by the artist) is 210 cm tall. Although this version looks like smoothly polished soapstone, it is actually made from fibreglass, a much lighter material.

title: From the Clouds to the Water
address: Killarney Dry Pond (N.W. corner of 28th Avenue and 30th Street S.W.)
short_desc: A collection of forged and wrought iron railing panels and benches make up this multi-piece public art installation.
desc1: Natural materials are combined with traditional blacksmithing techniques to create these functional works of art, which contribute a sense of movement and energy to this park-like location.
desc2: The bench design depicts cloud formations encompassed by a gently flowing framework, keeping with the organic theme of the site. The three panels in the railings have an integrated, continuous flow depicting elements of nature including the sun, rain cloud formations, stone and underground river system.

title: Utility Box
address: Flint Road S.E. at Fairmount Drive S.E. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Untitled
address: Prince's Island Park (698 Eau Claire Ave. S.W.)
short_desc: This elegant, two-part sculpture was created to commemorate a marriage.
desc1: Like a linear drawing in space, each section is made up of a vertical steel rod, intersected by an open-ended triangular shape, topped by a small ball.  Although they share structural components, the parts are not identical. The more emphatic bend of the larger straighter form is reciprocated by the gently curving arch of the smaller form, like partners bowing to each other in a graceful dance.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.E. and 14th Street N.E. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.W. and Shaganappi Trail N.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Recollections (heating shelter glass)
address: McKnight/Westwinds LRT Station (6200 36th St. N.E.)
short_desc: This public artwork is one of four installations at this LRT station.
desc1: Located in the glass heating shelters on the LRT platform, these spheres of colour appear to be dots from a distance, dancing around the glass. But as viewers draw closer it is clear these dots contain photographs of people living everyday life.
desc2: A vital component of this public art project was the inclusion of community residents in the creation of the piece. One of four installations located at the McKnight/Westwinds LRT station, Recollections invites the viewer to learn more about the community members living in the area.
desc3: A call went out to Calgarians living in the N.E. to contribute images of their lives. From a historical photograph of Mrs. Brown with her brand new stove to an image of a resident's parents married in India in 1945, these photographs provide viewers a glimpse into significant personal, historical and community events; all of the elements that make this community a unique and special place.

title: Utility Box
address: 24th Avenue S.W. and Fourth Street S.W. (N.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Edmonton Trail N.E. and First Avenue N.E. (N.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Bow Trail S.W. at 37th Street S.W. (N.W.)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.W. and Hamptons Blvd. N.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Steward
address: The City of Calgary Water Centre (625 Spiller Road S.E.)
short_desc: A collaborative effort between the artist and a landscape architect has transformed this garden into a functional work of art; one which draws our attention to our use and re-use of water.
desc1: Original earth cast vessels help to define this space and serve to illustrate the water harvest cycle which purposefully occurs on the Water Centre site. Representing the ancient practice of collecting and transporting water in clay pots, these vessels are directly integrated into the garden's self-sustainable irrigation system.
desc2: The man-formed river beds feed water from the building's roof throughout the landscape and past the benches designed by the artist where one may pause to reflect on the surrounding natural environment.

title: World War One Memorial
address: Central Memorial Park (12 Avenue at 3rd Street S.W.)
short_desc: Located in front of the Memorial Park Library in Calgary’s Central Memorial Park, this soldier stands as a perpetual reminder of the lives lost in the First World War. He raises his rifle in his right hand, perhaps as a gesture of resolve or victory, and holds his helmet in his left hand.
desc1: Made by artist Coeur-de-Lion MacCarthy, this bronze sculpture was donated to the City of Calgary in 1924 by a women's charitable organization called the Imperial Order Daughters of the Empire (IODE).
desc2: Born in England in 1881, Coeur-de-Lion MacCarthy moved to Montreal in 1918.  The son of an artist, he is known for a number of other bronze busts and sculptures located across Canada.

title: Utility Box
address: Macleod Trail S at 75th Ave S.W. (N.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.W. and Edgebrook Blvd. N.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: The Language of Life
address: Thornhill Aquatic and Recreation Centre (6715 Centre St. N.W.)
short_desc: Four large black and white photographs mounted by the entryway of this facility feature athletes suspended in motion.
desc1: Known for exploring art through non-digital photography, the artist was able to use multiple exposures (the act of exposing the same section of film repeatedly to light) to create these fascinating images which represent activities occurring at this Centre.
desc2: Highlighting the movement of an athlete's body while in motion, the sports of Tai chi, hockey, swimming and weight training have been captured as if frozen in time.

title: Utility Box
address: 26th Avenue S.W. at 14th Street S.W. (N.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: The Colour of Snow
address: Crowfoot LRT Station (1860 Scurfield Dr. N.W.) south glass window
short_desc: Conceptually and visually linked to the railings on the nearby interchanges, the artwork in these glass windows is inspired by the artist's first visit to Calgary.
desc1: The background image of the setting sun was originally captured by the artist as she flew into Calgary for her first site visit. The dramatic colours were translated from a photograph into a watercolour-like glass composition. This was combined with snowflake images, designed to highlight their distinctive molecular structures, in the hopes of drawing the viewer's attention to the unique forms that are built by nature, in an environment built by man.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.E. and Harvest Hills Gate N.E. (S.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Luminous Crossings
address: Downtown West - Kerby LRT Station (10th St. S.W.)
short_desc: This interactive public art installation consists of 20 components: two large-scale vertical sculptures, plus three hanging works, on four stations located at either end of the Seventh Avenue LRT line.
desc1: Referencing the idea of the living room or waiting area, there are four chandelier-like hanging sculptures in each canopy of the east and west gateway stations that give the waiting areas of the platforms a different quality. Additionally, their changing light show is a pleasant surrounding while waiting for the train.

title: Family of Horses
address: Municipal Building plaza level, 800 Macleod Tr. S.E
short_desc: Three unsaddled horses stand quietly on concrete steps of the City plaza, reminding us of the beauty of nature and wide open spaces of the prairie.
desc1: In this way, they offer temporary respite from the frenzy of our urban lives. They also speak to family. The mare turns to her foal while the stallion, standing behind them on higher ground, keeps a watchful eye.

title: Utility Box
address: 17th Avenue S.W. and 45th Street S.W. (S.E. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Bow Trail S.W. and Canterbury Drive S.W. (N.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Celebrations
address: Vivo Recreation Centre (11950 Country Village Link N.E.)
short_desc: This vibrant 20 piece installation reflects on and celebrates the activities which patrons of Vivo Recreation Centre may participate in on site.
desc1: Active and passive users of this facility will all see themselves reflected in these paintings which enliven the architecture of the centre's main wall. Spanning almost 90 feet, this multi-painting installation features skaters, hockey players and spectators, ensuring visitors know about the diversity of activities available throughout the complex.
desc2: Similarly, colours and stripes which are incorporated throughout the composition were directly inspired by the markings found on the gym floors within the facility; animating the motion captured in the figures, providing a sense of spontaneity and fun.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.W. and Sarcee Trail N.W. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Offering to Selene from an Elephant God
address: 540 5 Avenue S.W. (end of +15)
short_desc: Artist Isla Burns is known for her welded steel sculptures. This work, which is made of carefully balanced three-dimensional shapes, is a good example of the artist's skill with metal.
desc1: Burns was born in India and lived in Scotland prior to coming to Canada. Trained in Calgary and Edmonton, she has exhibited her works across Canada and around the world. She also has a number of public artworks installed permanently in Edmonton and Calgary
desc2: Although this work is abstract, its title, "Offering to Selene from the Elephant God", makes reference to a trip the artist took to the country of her birth. It also makes reference to the artist's own spiritual growth.

title: Utility Box
address: MacLeod Trail S at 71st Ave S.W. (N.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: Country Hills Blvd. N.E. and Coventry Blvd. N.E. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Rhythms II
address: Village Square Leisure Centre (2623 56th St. N.E.)
short_desc: Two artful benches, full of whimsy, celebrate Village Square Leisure Centre and the services it provides to our community.
desc1: These functional sculptures use shapes and kinetic forms to provide a sense of movement, energy and vitality to connect the work to the theme of recreational activity. Bold colours represent the cultural vitality of the Centre, while images and motifs reflective of cultural groups are incorporated within, referencing the diversity of the community users of this facility.
desc2: Blue waves, Buddhist wheels, figures in motion and interactive activities invite you to sit, pause and maybe even play.

title: Utility Box
address: 14th Avenue N.W. and 14th Street N.W. (N.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Utility Box
address: McKenzie Town Blvd. S.E. and 52nd Street S.E. (S.W. corner)
desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Luminous Crossings
address: Downtown West - Kerby LRT Station (10th St. S.W.)
short_desc: This interactive public art installation consists of 20 components: two large-scale vertical sculptures, plus three hanging works, on four stations located at either end of the Seventh Avenue LRT line.
desc1: These illuminated sculptures are integrated with Calgary's LRT system to change colours when the train arrives, docks and leaves the station. The structures of the sculptures are developed from images of rail transportation, connecting the artwork directly to the purpose and use of this site.

title: Conversation
address: Stephen Avenue Mall at 1st St. S.W.
short_desc: This humorous sculpture is part of The Businessman Series. The artist explained that his life-size figures, set on the ground, replace statues of classical heroes mounted on high pedestals.
desc1: Here, two businessmen, recognizable by their clothing and briefcases, are intently focused on each other. Their exchange seems more pointed than amicable. Leaning forward as he speaks, one man gestures emphatically, while his calm colleague tries to reassure him with a gentle touch to his arm.

title: Armillary Sundial
address: Calgary Zoo by Devonian Conservatory, 1300 Zoo Road N.E.
short_desc: Look at the centre of this sculpture: do you see the Earth? Known as an armillary sphere or armillary sundial, this work is a model of the celestial globe, centred on the Earth.
desc1: The artist who made this work describes it as 'a teaching tool to explain the movement of the sun and the construction of time.'
desc2: Surrounded by benches that represent each of the four seasons, this installation encourages the viewer to think about growing cycles and the passage of time.
desc3: This sphere was a gift to the people of Calgary from the Calgary Horticultural Society in celebration of its 100th anniversary in 2008.

title: Roseta
address: Devonian Gardens (317, 7 Avenue S.W.)
short_desc: This work was a gift to the City of Calgary from Mexico, and was created by one of that country's most celebrated contemporary sculptors. Sebastián's works can be seen around the world.
desc1: Made of metal and measuring over three metres (approximately 10 feet) high, it is an abstract work with elegant, curving lines, and is a good example of the geometric forms for which the sculptor is best known.
desc2: But this sculpture, titled "Roseta", is also distinct within his body of work because of its purple finish. Sebastián has used this colour on only a few of his sculptural works.
desc3: Prior to settling in Calgary, "Roseta" was in an exhibition that travelled to various locations in North America.

title: The Oarsman
address: Elbow Dr. Between 30th Avenue and 29th Avenue S.W.
short_desc: This bronze sculpture commemorates the life of John Lecky (1940-2003), a Canadian businessman, athlete, outdoorsman, and philanthropist. Effie Lecky, his wife, donated it to the City of Calgary.
desc1: John Lecky contributed to Canadian sports in a number of ways, including as a rower in the 1960 Summer Olympics in Rome, Italy. Along with his teammates, Lecky won a silver medal at these games in the Men's Coxed Eights. Some 24 years later, he was Canada's Chef de Mission for the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, United States.
desc2: This sculpture shows the athlete in a very dynamic pose. He is just about to pull back his oar, perhaps helping to propel his team to victory.
desc3: "The Oarsman" was created by Robert Spaith, a Calgary-born artist. Although he creates sculptures of a variety of subjects, he is best known for works depicting horses and aspects of cowboy culture.

title: Alberta Foothills Morning
address: North Mount Pleasant Arts Centre (523 - 27 Avenue NW)
short_desc: In this large-scale ceramic mural, Calgary-born artist Ed Drahanchuk offers a 1960's vision of Alberta life and industry.
desc1: The artist uses both overhead and side perspectives to show off the mural's subjects: farm fields with tractor tracks are seen from overhead, while a cart, cows, shafts of wheat, oil derricks, and mountains are seen from the side. These subjects are made from textured slabs of clay, and are suitable for viewing close-up or from a distance.
desc2: This mural, which weighs over 8000 kg (17 000 lbs) and measures 3.35 x 4.88 m (11 x 16 feet), is believed to be one of the first ceramic murals made in Calgary.
desc3: It was commissioned by the Municipal District of Rocky View for its Calgary office, and was originally built into a wall on a building on 16th Avenue NE. When the building had to be demolished as part of the widening of 16th Avenue in 2005-2006, the mural was carefully relocated to its current home at the North Mount Pleasant Arts Centre.

title: roger that
artist: Bill Pechet with Gabe Daly and Sara Zonousi of Pechet Studio
address: Tuscany LRT Station (Tuscany Springs Boulevard and Eamon Road N.W.)
short_desc: This public art installation spans both sides of Tuscany LRT station, which is in the centre of two north west communities, Rocky Ridge and Tuscany.
desc1: This work explores the way movement, position, distance and time can all influence our perception of what we see.  A series of sculptural installations merge to form two, 12 meter high sculptures, composed of 440 amber coloured safety lights. As the viewer moves throughout the site the sculptures begin to shift and change form.
desc2: From individual poles, seemingly placed in a disordered context, to a precise circle made up of fractional elements, this engaging work is meant to foster a cross-highway dialogue; as though neighbours were chatting over a fence.
desc3: If you're there as the sun is descending, stop and watch the lights gradually and randomly emerge to further shift and change your perception of roger that.

title: Boer War Memorial
address: Central Memorial Park (12 Avenue at 3rd Street S.W.)
short_desc: This huge, magnificent monument was meant to arouse lofty sentiments and patriotism.
desc1: A longstanding tradition, the equestrian statue was an especially fitting format to honour the 500 volunteers who travelled to South Africa from Alberta with their own horses. As horsemanship in the Boer war played a key role, the Montreal sculptor had a Western horse shipped to his studio.
desc2: The unknown mounted soldier is dressed in the uniform of Lord Strathcona's Horse regiment.

desc1: The Utility Box Program started in 2010 as a pilot project initiated by The City of Calgary Roads. Initially conceived as a highly successful graffiti abatement measure, widespread popularity enabled the program to grow and become permanent in 2011.

title: Bow Passage Overlook
address: Pearce Estate Park (1440 17A St. S.E.)
short_desc: This engaging environmental artwork reframes how we look at the practice of public art and its ability to impact our physical and natural spaces.
desc1: By connecting the built environment with the natural, this artwork allows visitors to reframe how they engage with urban and natural spaces.  Utilizing native plant species along with locally sourced natural materials, the Overlook provides a unique opportunity to capture Calgary's natural beauty, while highlighting the dramatic land and waterscapes our city loves to enjoy.

title: Rhythms I
address: Village Square Leisure Centre (2623 56th St. N.E.)
short_desc: Two artful benches, full of whimsy, celebrate Village Square Leisure Centre and the services it provides to our community.
desc1: These functional sculptures use shapes and kinetic forms to provide a sense of movement, energy and vitality to connect the work to the theme of recreational activity. Bold colours represent the cultural vitality of the Centre, while images and motifs reflective of cultural groups are incorporated within, referencing the diversity of the community users of this facility.
desc2: Blue waves, Buddhist wheels, figures in motion and interactive activities invite you to sit, pause and maybe even play.

title: Past, Present and Future
address: James Short Park, 115 4th Avenue S.W.
short_desc: Gernot Kiefer's limestone sculpture is an artistic representation of the progression of people though time.
desc1: Roughly resembling a human head, this sculpture has marks on its surface, intended to represent the time periods referenced in the work's title: the past, present and future. Near the base of the sculpture, the rough surface suggests the challenges of the distant past.
desc2: Marks near the middle of the sculpture are placed closer together, mixed with sections of smooth stone, suggesting that the present provides a way of life that is both complex and perhaps less challenging than the past.
desc3: The upper portion of the sculpture is very smooth, suggesting the many possibilities of the future: what will humans do next?
